div3.p:
--A Substitute, to join a company in the 21st Mississppi regiment of volunteers.
A liberal price given.
Inquire at the Spotswood House, Room 30.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --I wish to employ a Substitute Apply to me immediately on Bank street.

div3.head: A Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For whom a liberal price will be paid.
Persons who are exempt from service under the provisions of the conscript act, would do well to call at No. 9 Linwood House, Main street. The company is composed of gentlemen.
Room, No. 9, Linwood House.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute.
None need apply unless over thirty-five Apply at Pleasants & Frayser's office,
20th st., between Mainand Franklin.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Any good Virginian or Kentuckian, not subject to conscription, can go as a Substitute in a first-rate Regiment, at a high prcie, by calling to-day at the sign of the Tobacco Agency, corner Virginia and Cary streets.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute, to go in a first-rate Georgia company of infantry, under the heroic Jackson.
A gentleman whose health is impaired, will give fair price for a substitute.
Apply immediately at Room, No. 13, Post-Office Department, third story, between the hours of 10 and 3 o'clock.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute for Cavalry service.
Call on

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute, to serve in a Mississippi regiment, for whom a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at the Arlington House, to "J. M.," No. 1.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Substitute, for a conscript.
None need apply under the age of 45 years. Apply at the office of Thos. J. Bagry, No. 8 Wall street, under St. Charles Hotel, where the advertiser can be seen.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 25, Number 14, page 2.

div3.p:
The lesson for the day on which the grape series of battles began that raised the siege of Richmond, was the 19th chapter of 24 Kings, when the King of Amyria with beestings equal to these of McClellan, has beleaguered with a vast army and the King of Judah is in great alarm lest the city should be taken.
The whole chapter is well worth reading.
We extract the following verses for their singular appropriateness.
Therefore thus saith the Lord concerning the King of Assyria.
He shall not come into this city, Nor shoot arrow therein, nor come before it with shields, nor east a bank against it. By the way he came, by the same shall he turn, and shall not come into this city saith the Lord.
For I will defend the city to save it," &c. "And it came to pass that night, that the angel of the Lord went out , and smote in the camp of the Assyrisus an hundred four score and five them.
send." "So King of Assyria departed and went and returned."

div3.head: McClellan's address to his army.
div3.p:
McClellan sets up a lugubribus howl in his late address to his army about being set upon in his march by people of his "own race," who treated him in the most abominable manner.
What an ungrateful people not to permit themselves to be terminateed by their "own race," and how interrupt the reports march, which in McClellann's case, was a march , with his the chickahaminy and his fate to the . there over .

div3.head:
[correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
the traveling sick and wounded
div3.p:
Messes. Editors: Can you not through the colnimis of your excellent paper, (so widely circulated) make an appeal in behalf of the lynchburg sick and wounded on the various railroads coming South from Richmond.
Are you aware--can the Departments be aware — that these poor sufferers are but in the care without attendant, and without water to drink or to moisted the dressings of the wounded; and that the conductors never get them any at the stations which they pass?
Not even &c they provide seats enough for these, our"brave defenders."
The platforms are often crowded with sick, wounded, or pate wend "," hardly able to , yet obliged to train every nerve in order in hold on to their precarious position; exposed to hot sun of rain.
Only to-day have I attended the funeral of a brave , (the third son offered by a widowed mother) wounded in one of the battles; and his death was brought about less from his wound than from exposure on the of the car, for causing in the wound which spread over his whole body.
Many poor fellows here, hair-crazed with and hungrer, after this eleven hours travel — some go it is not possible to this crying .

div3.head:
Glorious News!
capture of Entire army.
the prisoners paroled.
div3.p: --The Memphis Bullet (Yankee.) exire, of Friday, states that Gen. than has captured Gen. with 8,000 prisoners.
The officers were detained, the men wereroled.

Preparations were making in Memphis for send.
during Curtis's men home.

div3.head: An Infaments order — Banishment of citizens of Memphis.
div3.p:
--A special dispatch to the Tribune, dated Grenade, July 14, states that the Memphis papers, of the 11th, contain an order from Gen. Grant, banishing from the city, after five days notice, the families of all persons connected in any manner with the Confederate army, or holding office under the Confederate Government, or holding since, county or municipal offices, and claiming to owe allegiance to the Confederate States.
The same rule is applied to families of those who have come South.
This order will expel fully two thirds of the families from Memphis.

div3.head: The bombardment of Vicksburg.
div3.p: --Four gunboats and one mortar boat remain in sight of Vicksburg.

div3.head: Brute Butler.
div3.p: --The brute Butler has arrested several persons in New Orleans for reporting McClellan's defeat.

div4.p: In Henrico county, at the residence of her husband, Henry Cox, Mrs. Lucy Cox, in the 49th year of her age.
Her funeral will take place from her husband's residence at 10 o'clock this morning, 16th inst.
Petersburg papers please copy.
On Tuesday afternoon, the 15th, at 7 o'clock, Miss Ada O.Butler, daughter of Wm. F. and Virginia J. Butler, aged 23 years.

Her funeral will take place from the residence of her father, corner of 12th and Marshall streets, on Thursday morning at 10 o'clock. The friends of the family are invited to attend without further notice.
At the residence of his uncle, William H. Woodward, on Thursday, 10th inst., of typhoid fever, Julian T. Derndon, aged 18 years, a member of company R, 4th Virginia cavalry.
On Sunday morning, 13th inst., at 12 o'clock. Mrs. Mildred Lorman, aged 42 years.
Lynchburg papers please copy

In this city, at the residence of his uncle, B. Bragg. Esq., Robert J. Bragg, youngest son of Thomas and Mary Bragg, of Fluvanna county, Va., in the 19th year of his age. He was stricken down while at his post in the defense of his country.
He was a good soldier, a dutiful son, and true Christian, having embraced religion about a year ago, and since then gave evidence of the purity of the profession he had made.

lg.l: Thou art gone to the grave, but we will not deplore
Though sorrows and darkness encompass the
Thy Saviour has passed its portal before thee.
And the lamp of His love is thy guide through
Thou art gone to the grave, and its mansion for
Perchance they weak spirit in fear lingered long;
But the mild rays of Paradise beamed on thy waking.
And the sound which thon heard'st was the sera.

div4.p: Religious Herald please copy.

div4.head: Funeral notice.
div4.p: The funeral of Fontaine Carlton, son of Benoni Carlton, of King and Queen county, will take place from the residence of Mr. James Pendleton, this morning, at 10 o'clock.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Lt. H. H. Roberts.--Killed in the late battle near Richmond, Va. June 26th, Lt. H. H. Roberts, company C. 35th Regiment Georgia Volunteers, in the 21st year of his age.

He was a dutiful son, a kind and affectionate brother, a brave and efficient officer, and a patient and pious Christian.
He was among the first to volunteer to drive back the dark tide of invasion which threatened to desolate his native South.
He has sealed his devotion to her cause by offering life itself upon Liberty's shrine.
An aged father and numerous friends and relatives mourn his untimely loss, but "Not as those without hope."
Though his remains may slumber in distant land, far from home and loved ones, yet, methinks kindred spirits will watch with a jealous care o'er the sleeping dust of one with so many virtues and so few vices.
And though often the tear of sorrow trickles down my check, yet judgment whispers that he fell at the post of duty, that our loss is his gain, and that he is now of the number of those "Who rest from their labors, and whose works follow them."
Atlanta (Ga.) Southern Confederacy please copy.

Among the many gallant spirits who fell on the field of carnage, in the fight before Richmond, was young Harry Williams, son of J. Buxton Williams, Esq., of Warren county, N. C. This noble boy was a member of the Warren Rifles, and was shot in the forehead while bearing the flag "with his face to the foe."
Rushing forward with youthful enthusiasm in the great conflict for independence, he was actuated by the dictates of duty and patriotism, the two highest incentives that animate the bosom of the soldier.
A chivalrous and magnanimous youth, of genial temper and sprightly talents, he was much beloved around the family niche, and greatly admired and esteemed among his acquaintances, as such a generous soul over will be. His death shrouds the family circle in a deep cloud of gloom, which is relieved, to some extent, by a "silver lining" in the contemplation of the manly virtues which marked his brief career.
It is a source of consolation to know that his life, though short, was of sufficient duration to stamp the lot press of a salutary influence on his associates, and particularly on his younger brothers.
Perhaps it is well that he died just on the verge of manhood, ere his pure mind had come n contact with the wickedness of earth in all its horrid enormity, and that his spirit fled hence calmly and peacefully, with the flag that he loved so ardently by his side.
Died, on Saturday, the 12th July, of wounds received in the late battle before Richmond, Emanuel Wagstaff, in the 36th year of his age.

It is believed by all who attended him in his last illness that he had faith in the promises of our Savour.
He bore his sufferings with great fortitude, and we trust he is now enjoying a blissful eternity.
He was a member of company K, 14th regiment N. C. troops.
His wife reached him last Wednesday evening, after a fatiguing journey.
He could not be carried home conveniently; so he was interred decently in Oskwood Cemetery.
Died, of wounds received on the 27th of June, in the battle before Richmond, Lieut. Marion Harris, of company C, 19th Mississippi regiment.

He was among the first to draw his sword in defence of his beloved country.
He was ever kind and gentle, admired by all who knew him. He leaves a bereaved wife to mourn his loss.
Like a Christian hero, he was willing to meet his God.

lg.l: Yet why should death he linked with fear
A single breath, a low drawn sigh.
Can break the ties that bind us here.
And waft the spirit to the shy.

div4.p: Vicksburg papers please copy.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--farm, Negroes, Stock, &c., Located in the county of Goochland, Va.--The subscriber desires to purchase, as a homestead, a farm, containing about 150 acres of rich and productive land, five able-bodied farm hands, and two families of Negroes, Stock, &c., necessary to a proper cultivation of the farm, inthe county of Goochland, Va., in the neighborhood of Dover Mills.
For further particulars, address Geo. W. Burke, Esq., Flippos's Store, Caroline county, Va., of Stuart's cavalry, now, or, when recovered from his illness, at the headquarters of the Caroline Light Dragoons, of Stuart's cavalry, or myself, at Petersburg, Va., from 18th to 21st isnt., care of W. H. Tappey, Esq.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Servant to go North.
A lday, going North, wishes a servant immediately, to take care of her child, two years old. Address, "A. B. C.," at this city.

div3.head:
Headquarters Cavalry brigade,
Camp Asbby, July 8, 1862.
div3.p: The following named soldiers, belonging to the 1st Cavalry Battalion, commanded by Captain W. H. Harness, having deserted from their companies, will be dealt with as the law directs:

table.head: Company a, Capt. G. W. Myers.

div3.p: Thirty dollars will be paid for the apprehension and delivery at these Headquarters, and fifteen dollars for their lodgment in Jail.
The assistance of all soldiers and loyal citizens is earnestly solicited in arresting and bringing these deserters to trial.
div3.closer:
By order
Brig. Gen. B. H. Robertson.
Walter K. Martin, A. A. General. jy 16--3t*

div3.p:
Thirty dollars reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery in jail of Edward Mullin, an Irishman received into the 8th Regiment Virginia volunteers as a substitute, on the 25th of June, and deserted on the night of the 26th.
Said Mullin is about 5 feet 7 inches high, dark complexion, hair and eyes.

The following named men are also advertised as deserters from the 8th Va. Reg't: Privates Geo. Roach and Pierce Noland, from Company C; Serg't A. J. Morris, Privates B. S. Minor, D. M. Sloper and J. D. Shrieve, from Company D; Chas. Jones, Company E; Samuel R. Poulton, Company H; Jno. Mathers, Ben. Mathers and George W. Shores, Company I; Serg't George W. Brooke and Corporal Chas. H. Buchanon, Company K.
The battle flag of some regiment, that was lost in the Friday's fight at Gaines's Mill, can be obtained by the owners at my quarters.

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p:
--John W. Lucas, a member of my company.
Said Lucas is about 25 years of age, stout built, about 5 feet 10 inches high, light hair, blue eyes.
He lives in Hanover county, near what is known as the Yellow Tavern.
The reward prescribed by law will be paid for his delivery to me or to any prison in this city.

closer.signed: Capt. Co. D, 10th Reg't Cavalry, Stuart's Brig.

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p:
Henry M. Wioks, a member of my company.
Said Wicks is about 23 years of age, dark hair, black eyes, genteel looking, about 5 feet 9 inches high, stout built, and reported himself to be from Texas.
The usual reward prescribed by law will be paid for his delivery to me or to any prison in this city.

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p:
--Marquis Hayes, a member of my company.
Said Hayes is about 26 years of age, 5 feet 10 inches high, well proportioned, black hair, grey eyes, rather quick spoken, and represented himself to be from Tennessee--The reward prescribed by law will be paid for his delivery to me, or to any of the prisons in this city.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
Deserted from Col J. Luclus Davis's camp, on the night of the 7th inst., C.C. Clark alias C. Reny, while under arrest for various charges.
Said Clark is about 20 years of age, about 5 feet 8 inches high, light hair, blue eyes.--The reward prescribed by law will be paid for his delivery to me.

div3.head: Thirty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward is offered for the apprehension and delivery to me of Alexander Trax, a private in my company of light artillery.
He is German by birth; 38 years of age; 5 feet 5 inches high; stoutly built; dark complexion, and has a peculiarly hoarse voice.
He is supposed to be loitering around Richmond, which was his place of residence previous to his enlistment.
He absented himself from camp about a week ago.
div3.closer:
John A. Coke.
Captain Williamsburg Artillery.
Artillery Camp, at Blakey's Mill,
Near Richmond, July 5, 1862. jy 7--5t*

div3.p:
Every member of the "Hampden Artillery" is hereby ordered to report immediately to Camp.
Delinquents from roll-call will be regarded and treated as deserters.
Roll-call punctually at 11 o'clock A. M. to-day.
div3.closer:
By order of
Capt. W. H. Caskie jy 16--1t

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
All members of the Richmond Grays, Company G, 12th Virginia regiment, who are now absent, and not sick or suffering from wounds, will at once report to me, at camp near Falling Creek, six milles from Richmond, or be published as deserters.
The sick will send Surgeon's certificate weekly.
div3.closer:
By order.
E. W. Branch,
1st Lt. Com'g. jy 16--3t*

div3.head: Attention, Cumberland troop.
div3.p: --The absent members of this company are ordered to report themselves in camp immediately or send the certificate of an army surgeon of their inability to do so, else they will be published, arrested and punished as deserters.
div3.closer:
George H. Mathews, Jr.,
First Lieut. Com'g Co. G, 3d Va Cavalry.
Cavalry Camp, near Richmond, July 14, 1862. jy 15--3t*

div3.head: Notice to North Carolina State Troops.
div3.p: --All Packages and Boxes sent to Regiments by Express or Freight, can be found at the N. C. Depot, No. 228 Main st. Also Boxes containing Clothing, &c, from the State Quarter master, marked to the Colonels of Regiments.
All Members of Lieut. Col. Pate's Battallon absent on furlough or without leave, are ordered to report immediately to the 5th Regiment Virginia Cavalry, or be published and treated as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order:
J. W. Gregory.
Report to officer in charge of Recruiting Office, on Main, three doors below 9th st. Jy 7--

div3.head:
Office of Chief Quartermaster,
army of Northern Va,
Richmond, July 12.
div3.p: All Quartermasters, or other persons having in their possession captured Horses or Mules, will at once turn them over to Captain W. S. Woop, A. Q. M. at Bacon Quarter Branch.

div3.head: Notice to Commandants of companies.
div3.p: --Commandants of companies who desire to have their companies mustered into service or for pay; will find me at the office of Gen. Winder, during office hours.

closer.signed: Samuel T. Bayly, Capt P. A. C. S.,
A. A. Gen't and Mustering Officer.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--All members of the Charies City troop absent from any cause, are hereby ordered to report to this company at the camp of the 3rd Va. Cavalry.
All orderlies are relieved accept these with Gen Lee.
div3.closer:
By order of
Col. Wm. F. Goode
F. Gut,
Captan Commanding Company. jy 14--3t*

div3.head: Ten dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Catch the Thief.--A free negro named Geo. Belie.
Ville, who has been employed by the undersigned, absconded on the morning of the 13th, taking with him a lot of clothing &c.

George from the county of Hanover, about six feet high, and of very dark complexion.
He is in all probability lurking in the city of Richmond, or about the camps of some neighboring regiment.
I will pay a reward of $10 to any one who will apprehend and deliver the said boy to me, at the campment of the 2d Florida regiment, Gen. R. A. Pryer's brigade.
div3.closer:
John T. Suggs.
4th Sergeant Co. C,
2d Florida regiment jy 16--3t*

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will give the above reward for the apprehension of my Negro Man, Moses.
He left my son, Lieut. W. J. Warren, of the 21st Georgia regiment, in the neighborhood of Madison C. R. about the middle of May last, and is supposed to be lasting in that vicinity now. Moses is 5 feet 7 inches high, 23 years old, a dark mulatto, rather stoops in in the shoulders, slow of speech, and often matters in speaking, and were a monstache.

If he is apprehended and lodged in the City Jail in Richmond, I will pay the above reward, through my attorney, Henry Hudnall, Esq., of Richmond who is hereby authorized to act for me in the premises, and to whom application must be made.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway on Thursday, the 20th of June, a negro girl named Landonia, 12 years of age, of a brigh ginger bread color.
She had on ared check line dress, and a blue check drawn gingham net. She represents herself as a free girl.
The above reward of $20 will be paid for her delivery at Grady's Jail.

div3.head: Ran away $50 reward.
div3.p:
--From Reward.
ville. Albemarie county, Va., a Negro Man about 25 years old, black, and heavy set named Tom. The above negro was purchased about ten days ago, in Richmond, of J. H. Martin.
The negro is from Caroline county, and may be making his way back.
The above reward will be paid it delivered to me, or lodged in any jail so that I can get him.
div3.closer:
John B. Davis.
Richmond Va. jy16--5t*

div3.head: Ten dollars reward.
div3.p:
--My boy Alfred.
left the Packet office on Sunday morning 13th inst., for the camp of the 18th Virginia regiment, and has not been heard from since.
Alfred is 17 years of age, very black, about 5 feet high had on a gray military sult, with knapsack and had with him a basket of chickens, and other supplies.
I will give ten dollars for his delivery to me at the 18th Virginia camp on the Darbytown road, 2½ miles below the city or to Major B.B. Ayres, of the American Hotel, and necessary at penses.
Any information as to his whereabout, will be thankfuly received and liberally rewarded.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p:
--My negro boy John, 12 years old, absented himself about two weeks ago. When last heard from he was at one of the neighboring camps.
He has large eyes, quite abrewd and is apt to misrepresent as to his owner name &c. I will pay a suitable reward for his return.
div3.closer:
Chas. E. Whitlocr
Broad, between 23d and 24th stc. jy 14--6t*

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on the night of the 7th inst, a negro boy named MacKENZIEenzie.
He is 22 years of age, low, heavy set, with bad looking eyes.
Said boy was brought from Essex county, six months ago. I will pay the above reward, if delivered to me in Richmond.

div3.head: Ran away.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on the 15th of June, a Negro Man, Lewis.
Said negro is about 21 years old five feet six or seven inches high, very black, and stout, had on when he left a black frock coat and military cap. I will give the above reward if delivered to me in Lynchburg; or $30 if secured so I can get him.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from Chimborazo Hospital, about a week ago, a negro boy named Hudson.
He is about 20 years of age, knock-kneed, black, and very good at whistling.
He may be at some of the camps.
He is about 4½ feet high.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to us, or at Chimborazo Hospital.

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
Ranway, about the 25th of June last, a negro woman named Mima, who calls herself Mima Harris.
She is about 30 years old, bright mulatto, considerably freckled, and is supposed to be lurking about the lines of the army.
The above reward will be paid for her capture and delivery to Hector Davis, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my factory in Danville, on Sunday, June 1st, my negro man Thornton, who calls himself Thornton Gregory.
It is supposed that he will attempt to get to Richmond.
I will give the above reward on his delivery to me in Danville, or to Mr. Coleman Wortham in Richmond.
Thornton is of black complexion, about five feet ten inches high, spare make, is a boy of good countenance.
He had on when he left dark pants and coat and a light vest.

div3.head: Lost Negro Man found.
div3.p:
--On Monday July 7th.
Conductor Taylor left in my charge a rail, well formed, very black Negro Man, supposed to be about twenty years old, with a small scar on his forehead and a scar entirely across on the outside of the right bend.
He says his name is Calvin, and belongs to Quintus Corchran.
of Sumter county, Ala. Livingston District.
The owner of the boy will please come forward, prove property pay charges and take possession of him.

closer.signed: General Preight Agent R. & D. R. H.

div3.head: Runaways.
div3.p: --Absconded from the service of the James River and Kanawha Company on Sunday last, two negro men, named Arthur and Edward.

Arthur belongs to Mrs. Ellis, in Spotsylvar county.
He is about thirty years of age, is of low stature, brown color, flat face, with a scar on it and has one defective eye.

Edward belongs to Mrs. Randolph, in Fan quire county.
He is about sixty years of age, of low stature and brown color.
The company win pay what the law allows and ten dollars besides as each of these men, if arrested and returned to Mr. Smith A. Thorp, Master Carpenter, near the first lock on the canal, three miles above this city.

closer.signed: Sup't J. R. and K. Canal

div3.head: Runaways.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from Second Sertion Richmond and Danville Railroad, the following Slaves.
The legal reward will be paid for their return at the office of the company in Richmond, or at any Station on the road — viz:
Washington; very dark, five feet nine or ten inches high; stammers a little when spoken to.
Nelson; stout balls, dark color, five feet seven or eight inches high.
Thomas; yellow complexion, rather slow in his movements, five feet nine or ten inches high
All the property of Wm. H. Buckner, of Caroline county, Va.

div3.head: One hundred and fifty dollars reward.
div3.p: --Will be paid for the delivery in Richmond of the three following slaves, virginia.

William Payne, a dark black man, about 5½ feet high, about 30 years old, stout and . He has spent most of his life in different tobacco factories in this city.
He was employed the early part of this year as teamster near Yorktown — say till the evacastion of the Peninsula by our troops.
He has a wife at Mrs. Fanny Caryer's upper end of Hanover.
He has probably gone there, or to some of our camps.
He absconded on the 9th inst.

Warwick. a bright mulatte, 19 or 20 years old, tall and slender.
He was hired this year at the Exchange Hotel, and absconded about three weeks ago, probably with a view of going over to the enemy, but probably could not enter their lines before the commencement of the recent battles on the Chickahominy.

Harris, a black boy, about 15 years old. He was hired to Geo. T. Booker, to work on his farm a few miles north of the Chickahominy.
He was seen with the enemy shortly before the battle of Hanover Court House.
One hundred and fifty dollars will be paid for the apprehension and delivery here of the three, of fifty dollars for any one of them.
